metadata.titleEn: Albedo dataset in 30m-resolution in the Heihe River basin (2012)
metadata.description: Used in environment and mitigation of small satellite constellation 30 m image of CCD sensor, after scaling, geometric correction and based on the Angle of the top of the atmosphere apparent reflectance grid regression (presents Bin) inversion algorithm inversion of surface shortwave albedo, choose the image Mosaic of cloud cover at least a month again become full of heihe river basin albedo distribution, projection method for UTM projection, the spatial resolution of 30 meters, time and frequency of 1 per month.The data file contains two bands, namely the black-sky albedo of local noon and the white-sky albedo corresponding to the solar Angle at the local noon, which are stored in the form of a short integer with a scaling factor of 0.0001.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the data is stored in rastrate raw format, the file name "ALBEDO_HJCCD_AB2_30_HEIHE_yyyymm", where yyyy represents the year and mm represents the month, for example, albedo_hjccd_ab2_30_heihe_201201.raw represents the surface albedo data of January 2012.
Data reading: Arcgis, Envi and other remote sensing software can be used to open and read.

background: The successful launch of this satellite can effectively compensate for the shortcomings of conventional ground monitoring methods, providing a new data source for large-scale, all-weather, real-time dynamic monitoring of environmental pollution, natural disasters, and ecological damage in our country. Currently, the methods for retrieving surface albedo for this type of sensor mainly include the direct estimation method based on top-of-atmosphere (TOA) radiation and the estimation method based on surface directional reflectance. The direct estimation method based on TOA radiation combines three physical processes: atmospheric correction, narrowband albedo calculation, and narrowband to broadband conversion, into a statistical analysis-based model, using TOA reflectance data from a single observation direction to calculate the surface broadband albedo.
research objective: To address the problem of surface albedo inversion using this type of sensor, this paper conducts a study on the inversion of surface albedo using high-quality bidirectional reflectance distribution function data as a prior dataset, based on the grid division of observation geometry. The surface albedo inversion algorithm proposed in this paper has high accuracy.
challenges: The limitations of band settings and the restricted observation angles constrain the application of HJ-1A/1B data in surface albedo retrieval. Incomplete cloud detection can reduce the accuracy of albedo retrieval.
methods: This article employs an improved linear kernel-driven model for simulating surface albedo, which adds a forward scattering kernel function to the original model, resulting in a linear kernel-driven model composed of four kernels: isotropic kernel, volume scattering kernel, geometric optics kernel, and forward scattering kernel. The study selects high-quality HJ-1A/1B data from August 2010 for inversion experiments. First, the atmospheric correction method proposed by Liu et al. is used for atmospheric correction to obtain surface reflectance data, and then albedo inversion experiments are conducted.
dataset: This paper uses high-quality MODIS bidirectional reflectance distribution function datasets to simulate the surface directional reflectance of HJ-1A/1B in four bands under different observation geometries for vegetation, bare soil, and ice and snow cover. High-quality HJ-1A/1B data from the Heihe River is selected to conduct inversion experiments for shortwave surface black and white sky reflectance.
findings: The results show that among the 54 sets of data that meet the validation criteria, 50 sets have an absolute error within 5%. The validation results indicate that the surface albedo inversion method proposed in this paper has high accuracy.

background: Land surface albedo is a critical parameter in surface-energy budget studies. Over the past several decades, many albedo products are generated from remote-sensing data sets. The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF)/Albedo algorithm is used to routinely produce eight day (16-day composite), 1-km resolution MODIS albedo products. When some natural processes or human activities occur, the land-surface broadband albedo can change rapidly, so it is necessary to enhance the temporal resolution of albedo product.
research objective: We present a direct-estimation algorithm for mapping daily land-surface broadband albedo from MODIS data.
challenges: Unfortunately, the ground-measured data are not suitable for direct comparison with satellite acquired data, as the scale of the ground-measured data is not compatible with the satellite data, and currently there are not enough ground-measured BRDF data sets to represent all the various land-cover types in a global scope.
methods: The polarization and directionality of the Earth’s reflectance-3/polarization and anisotropy of reflectances for atmospheric sciences coupled with observations from a Lidar BRDF database is employed as a training data set, and the 6S atmospheric radiative transfer code is used to simulate the top-of-atmosphere (TOA) reflectances. Then a relationship between TOA reflectances and land-surface broadband albedos is developed using an angular bin regression.
dataset: The POLDER-3 radiometer onboard the CNES/Parasol satellite provides multidirectional measurements of the Earth reflectances at six bands (the center wavelengths are 490, 565, 670, 765, 865, and 1020 nm). The POLDER-3/PARASOL BRDF database contains 13,887 samples (pixels) that present different landscapes at different locations with a spatial resolution of 6 km. The data set contains all types of IGBP classes, and it is distributed widely throughout the world.
findings: The comparison result shows that the overall accuracy of the direct-estimation algorithm, which is derived without doing atmospheric corrections, is consistent with the current widely used MCD43B3 product.

Definition.Question: What does 'angular bin regression' mean in the context of land-surface albedo estimation?
Definition.Answer: Angular bin regression is a method used to develop a relationship between top-of-atmosphere reflectances and land-surface broadband albedos by utilizing the angular data of reflectance measurements. It involves categorizing the reflectance data into bins based on angles and using these bins to perform regression analysis to estimate albedo values.

Definition.Question: What does 'BRDF' stand for and what is its role in surface reflectance studies?
Definition.Answer: BRDF stands for Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function. It characterizes how the reflectance of a surface changes with varying angles of illumination and observation. In surface reflectance studies, BRDF data are crucial for accurately modeling and estimating albedo, as they account for the anisotropic nature of reflectance.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of limited band settings and observation angles in HJ-1A/1B data compare to the challenges faced with the ground-measured data scale when mapping land-surface broadband albedo from MODIS data?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges with HJ-1A/1B data involve limited band settings and observation angles that restrict its application in albedo retrieval, while the challenges with ground-measured data for MODIS involve compatibility issues with satellite data scales and a lack of sufficient BRDF datasets to represent various global land-cover types.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods used for atmospheric correction and albedo retrieval differ between the improved linear kernel-driven model for HJ-1A/1B data and the direct-estimation algorithm used for MODIS data?
Comparison.Answer: The improved linear kernel-driven model for HJ-1A/1B data uses an atmospheric correction method and a model with four kernels, including a forward scattering kernel, for albedo retrieval. In contrast, the direct-estimation algorithm for MODIS data employs a relationship between top-of-atmosphere reflectances and land-surface broadband albedos using an angular bin regression without requiring atmospheric corrections.

Interpretation.Question: What implications can be drawn from the use of angular bin regression in calculating surface albedo from satellite data, and how might this method influence the accuracy of albedo estimations?
Interpretation.Answer: The angular bin regression method allows for the calculation of land-surface broadband albedos by establishing a relationship between top-of-atmosphere (TOA) reflectances and land-surface albedo, which can enhance the accuracy of albedo estimations by taking into account the angular variations in reflectance data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limitations of observing angles and band settings in land surface albedo inversion from satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations in observing angles and band settings can be attributed to the inherent design constraints of sensors like HJ-1A/1B, which restrict their application in surface albedo inversion. Additionally, incomplete cloud detection can reduce the accuracy of albedo inversion.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to enhance the temporal resolution of land-surface broadband albedo products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Enhancing the temporal resolution of albedo products is necessary because natural processes or human activities can cause the land-surface broadband albedo to change rapidly, necessitating more frequent data updates to capture these changes accurately.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in directly comparing ground-measured data with satellite-acquired data for land surface albedo studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises because the scale of ground-measured data is not compatible with satellite data. Additionally, there is a lack of sufficient ground-measured BRDF datasets to represent all the diverse land-cover types globally, which complicates direct comparison.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a single observation direction for atmospheric top reflectance data in estimating land surface broadband albedo?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a single observation direction for atmospheric top reflectance data can simplify the estimation process of land surface broadband albedo by merging atmospheric correction, narrowband to broadband conversion, and other processes into a statistical model. However, this approach might limit the accuracy of the albedo estimation due to the reduced information from varied observation angles.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the limited band setting and observation angles of HJ-1A/1B satellites affect the applicability of their data for surface albedo retrieval?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The limited band setting and observation angles of HJ-1A/1B satellites restrict the accuracy and application of their data for surface albedo retrieval. These limitations hinder the ability to capture comprehensive reflection information, which can lead to less accurate albedo estimations, especially in varied and complex surface conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why explore the development of algorithms capable of mapping daily land-surface broadband albedo from remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to improve the temporal resolution of albedo products, as land-surface broadband albedo can change quickly due to natural processes or human activities. Enhanced temporal resolution is critical for effectively monitoring these changes and improving the accuracy of environmental assessments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to address the challenges of limited band settings and observation angles in albedo retrieval from satellite data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address the challenges of limited band settings and observation angles in albedo retrieval from satellite data, improvements in linear kernel-driven models can be employed. This involves adding additional kernels such as forward scattering kernels to enhance the model's capabilities. Atmospheric correction methods can also be applied to obtain accurate surface reflectance data, which can then be used for albedo retrieval experiments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can datasets from different satellite sources be integrated to improve the temporal resolution of albedo products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Datasets from different satellite sources can be integrated by employing direct-estimation algorithms that map daily land-surface broadband albedo using data from sources like MODIS. A relationship between top-of-atmosphere reflectances and land-surface broadband albedos can be established using angular bin regression, which allows for enhanced temporal resolution without relying solely on ground-measured data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in simulating top-of-atmosphere reflectances using a Lidar BRDF database and atmospheric radiative transfer codes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Simulating top-of-atmosphere reflectances involves using a Lidar BRDF database as a training dataset, coupled with the 6S atmospheric radiative transfer code to simulate the reflectances. The process includes developing a relationship between these simulated reflectances and land-surface broadband albedos using angular bin regression, which aids in understanding and predicting albedo changes under various conditions.

Enablement.Question: What methods or algorithms enable the accurate retrieval of land surface albedo using satellite data in diverse geographic conditions?
Enablement.Answer: A direct-estimation algorithm using MODIS data and an angular bin regression enables the mapping of daily land-surface broadband albedo, providing accurate retrieval of land surface albedo across various geographic conditions.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in atmospheric correction techniques facilitate the enhancement of satellite-based albedo measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The use of improved atmospheric correction methods, such as those proposed by Liu et al., enables the acquisition of accurate surface reflectance data, which is essential for enhancing the precision of albedo measurements from satellite data.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset's observation geometry limitations impact the accuracy of land surface albedo retrieval?
Expectation.Answer: The limited observation angles can restrict the application of certain datasets in albedo retrieval tasks, as they may not capture the full range of reflectance anisotropies necessary for precise calculations. This can lead to decreased accuracy in the retrieval of land surface albedo data.

Expectation.Question: Why could challenges in cloud detection lead to reduced precision in albedo retrieval methods?
Expectation.Answer: Incomplete cloud detection can lower the precision of albedo retrieval since undetected clouds might introduce errors by affecting the reflectance data used in the retrieval process. Accurate cloud detection is crucial to ensure that only valid surface observations are considered.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the challenges posed by the limited wavelength bands and observation angles of certain remote sensing satellites when it comes to accurate surface albedo inversion?
Judgmental.Answer: The limited wavelength bands and observation angles of satellites like HJ-1A/1B pose significant challenges for accurate surface albedo inversion. These limitations restrict the applicability of the data for albedo retrieval, potentially leading to reduced precision. Furthermore, challenges in thorough cloud detection can impair the accuracy of albedo inversion, indicating the need for advanced algorithms and additional data sources to mitigate these issues.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for retrieving land surface albedo using remote sensing technology and identify any challenges associated with these methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Remote sensing technology employs methods such as using sensors like CCD on satellites and algorithms like the angular bin regression for data collection. Challenges include limited band settings, restricted observation angles, and issues with cloud detection which may affect the precision of albedo retrieval.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges of integrating ground-measured data with satellite-acquired data for land surface albedo studies and suggest possible solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include incompatibility in scale between ground-measured and satellite data and insufficient ground-measured BRDF datasets to cover various global land-cover types. Solutions could involve developing more comprehensive ground datasets and using advanced algorithms that account for these scale differences.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used for improving the temporal resolution of land surface albedo products and discuss their relevance.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include the POLDER-3/PARASOL BRDF database, which offers multidirectional measurements and covers various global landscapes. This dataset is relevant as it provides comprehensive samples that can aid in enhancing the temporal resolution of albedo products, especially when natural or anthropogenic changes occur rapidly.
